subject: Psychology
title: The James-Lange Theory
description: A short lesson to help you apply The James-Lange Theory.

hook.text: You don't run because you're afraid. You're afraid because you run. William James flipped emotion on its head.

buildup.text: In 1884, James proposed that bodily reactions come first and the conscious feeling of emotion comes second.

discovery.text: See a bear ‚Üí body responds (heart races, muscles tense) ‚Üí brain reads the body ‚Üí you feel fear.

twist.text: Critics argued: different emotions feel different, but many share the same body response. How do you tell them apart?

climax.text: Modern science shows James was partly right. Body feedback does influence emotional experience.

punchline.text: Sometimes the body feels first and the mind catches up.

quiz.question: What does the James-Lange theory propose?
options: Bodily reactions cause the feeling of emotion
Emotions and body responses are unrelated
